citeinfo.origin: University of South Florida College of Marine Science
citeinfo.title: Northwest Florida Bay Coastal Station Dataset - Coastal Ocean Monitoring and Prediction System (COMPS)

descript.abstract: The University of South Florida Coastal Ocean Monitoring and Prediction System (COMPS) Northwest Florida Bay coastal monitoring station is installed on a five-piling USCG structure located in four meters of water, one nautical mile SSW of Cape Sable, Florida. The parameters measured at this station are water level, wind speed and direction, wind gusts, barometric pressure, air temperature, relative humidity, water temperature, salinity, chlorophyll-a, and underwater transmittance. The data is transmitted from the station to the COMPS office at USF approximately every hour using the GOES satellite and is then made available on the COMPS website. Sensor heights on this station were referenced to NAVD 88 on November 12, 2002 at 21:21 UTC. Note that the only date reference for each data record is in the GOES transmission header and corresponds to transmission time. If the transmission time for data collected during the 23rd hour is after midnight, the date in the header will be one day ahead of the actual date of collection.
descript.purpose: The University of South Florida has implemented a real-time Coastal Ocean Monitoring and Prediction System (COMPS) for West Florida. COMPS consists of an array of instrumentation, both along the coast and offshore, combined with numerical circulation models, and builds upon existing in-situ measurements and modeling programs funded by various state and federal agencies. COMPS provides additional data needed for a variety of management issues, including more accurate predictions of coastal flooding by storm surge, safety and efficiency of marine navigation, search and rescue efforts, and fisheries management. COMPS also supports basic research programs.
descript.supplinf: The University of South Florida implemented COMPS in 1997 for West Florida as a State of Florida legislative initiative. The real-time and non real-time meteorological and oceanographic data collected from coastal stations and offshore buoy stations maintained by USF along the West Florida Shelf are part of the COMPS initiative. All USF-COMPS coastal stations are equipped with Aquatrak acoustic water level measurement sensors. The coastal stations also have a variety of meteorological and oceanographic sensors: RM Young anemometers for wind speed and direction, barometric pressure sensors, air temperature and realtive humidity sensors, rain gages, water temperature and conductivity sensors, fluorometers and transmissometers. Note that not all the stations have all these sensors. They are installed on each stations based on the need. COMPS buoy-mounted meteorological sensors consist of either the Coastal Environmental Systems Weatherpak 2000 system, modified to accommodate GOES telemetry, or the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute (WHOI) Improved METeorology (IMET) system, which has now evolved into the Air Sea Interaction METeorology (ASIMET) system, which is presently being manufactured by Star Engineering. The Weatherpaks measure wind speed and direction, air and water temperature, relative humidity, and barometric pressure. IMET and ASIMET measures the above parameters plus incoming short and long wave radiation and precipitation. (previous geoform was 'tabular digital data')

idinfo.useconst: Following academic courtesy standards, the COMPS Co-Directors (see Originator), the University of South Florida College of Marine Science, and the Grantor (see Data Set Credit) should be fully acknowledged in any subsequent publications in which any part of these data are used. Use of the data without completely reading and understanding the metadata is not recommended. Neither the University of South Florida, the USF College of Marine Science researchers, nor the State of Florida are responsible for the misuse of data from this database (see Distribution Liability).

cntperp.cntper: Dr. Mark E. Luther or Dr. Robert H. Weisberg

cntaddr.address: 140 7th Avenue South College of Marine Science University of South Florida

idinfo.datacred: The COMPS program is supported by the State of Florida and the University of South Florida, College of Marine Science. Northwest Floridabay station is maintained by the USF College of Marine Science and Florida Institute of Oceanography. Dr. Mark Luther and Dr. Bob Weisberg are the Co-directors of the COMPS Program. The COMPS field program directors, COMPS data manager, and COMPS system administrator and FIO personnel have also contributed to the dataset.
idinfo.native: The raw and de-coded data from this station is stored in SGI Linux and PC Windows based computers and are presently served on the internet.

attracc.attraccr: USF COMPS Coastal Stations Weather Monitoring System Accuracy (Northwest Florida Bay Coastal Station) Wind Speed: +/- 0.3 m/sec or 3% Wind Direction: 5 - 7.8 Deg. Air Temperature: +/-0.3 deg. C Water Temperature: +/-0.2 deg. C Water Level: Calibration: Standard: +/- 0.025% Optional: +/- 0.01% Nonlinearity: +/- 0.02% Precision : +/- 0.01% Stability, : 0 Drift, 1 Year Temperature Drift: <1 ppm/deg C Conductivity: Normalized to 25 Deg. C - +/- 1% over Range 0-30 deg C Non-Normalised - 0.2% over range 0-30 deg C Barometric Pressure:+/- 0.5 hPa (0.02 in Hg) @ 20 deg. C +/- 2.0 hPa (0.06 in Hg) over temp.range Relative Humidity:3% from 10 to 90% RH at 20 deg. C 4% from 0to10 and 90to100% RH at 20 deg. C Precipitation: +/- 0.4 mm per hour

dataqual.complete: The near real-time data telemetred from the Northwest Florida Bay Coastal Station data can be accessed via the website http://comps1.marine.usf.edu/nfb/. The Northwest Florida Bay Station website is updated every hour, and data for the past 24-hour in report form can be accessed via the website. Various Data Display (Time series and Wind Vector plots) plots (Past 24 hours and 5- Days) are also available for download from the website. The details of data format are also provided in the website. The decoded data files of the USF COMPS Anclote site can be accessed by pointing the browser to the URL:ftp://comps.marine.usf.edu/pub/nfb. The data format details are also available. For further details on data availability and access, please contact COMPS Program Data Manager. The station log of maintenance, problems, and observations relevant to the Sensor systems on the stations are maintained in College of Marine Science, University of South Florida, St. Petersburg, Florida. The raw data telemetred from the station are archived at College of Marine Science, University of South Florida. The raw data will be provided based on request to the Pricipal Investigators of the USF COMPS Project.

procstep.procdesc: A brief overview of the data processing steps of USFCMS COMPS Coastal and Offshore weather monitoring data is presented here. Detailed description of the processing scripts used are available at College of Marine Science, University of South Florida. USF has two downlink systems to acquire the coastal and offshore stations data via GOES: a Digital Direct Reading Ground Station (DDRGS) and a Domestic Satellite rebroadcast receiving system (DOMSAT). We also download our data from NESDIS using Local Readout Ground Station software package obtained from NOAA, NESDIS. The hourly data streams (meteorological and water parameters) received from coastal stations consist of ten 6-minute samples. The hourly data streams (measurements of meteorological parameters) that are received from the offshore stations consist of four 15-minute and three 20-minute samples for buoys equipped with Coastal Climate WeatherPak systems and USF/ASIMET systems respectively. The ADCP (velocities, direction) consist of one sample per hour. The salinity and temperature data consist of three 20 minute samples on IMET/ASIMET type buoys and two 30 minute samples on coastal climate weatherpak buoys. Once received the data are processed using decoder scripts written in C and Perl programming languages. Observations are then served to the public via the Internet at http://comps.marine.usf.edu. These data are also available via the NDBC who have direct access for input to the National Center for Environmental Prediction for improved marine weather forecasts at http://www.ndbc.noaa.gov/Maps/Florida.shtml. The most recent observations, graphics and reports (past one and five days duration) generated from the data are available for download from the individual station web site. Development of a web based data management system is in progress.

enttyp.enttypd: The attributes in this entity describe the observations made by the instruments at the station every six minutes. Column headers (attribute labels) are inserted ahead of each six-minute data record. NOTE: A header string containing GOES transmitter information and other station information is inserted approximately hourly. This header string contains the date of observation (see Overview Description for interpretation of this header string).

Conductivity

attr.attrdef: Primary Water Level NOTES: Water Level = (staff_offset) - (measured water level) - sensor offset. For example, Water Level = 10000 - 5356 - (-103) = 4747 millimeters above staff (benchmark) datum. This sensor is referenced to NAVD 88. See GOES header string for staff (benchmark) offset and sensor offset. See USF COMPS ftp site for sensor heights. Aquatrak sensor height is substituted for staff offset in the above equation to calculate water level relative to NAVD 88.

attrvai.attrvae: Accuracy is +/-0.025 percent of measurement. Calibration (Standard: +/-0.025%, Optional: +/-0.01%); Non-linearity: +/-0.02%; Precision: +/-0.01%; Stability: 0; One year temperature drift: 1 ppm/deg C

attr.attrdef: Secondary Water Level--measurement from the last hour at the same minute as a backup in case there is a problem with the data transmission NOTES: Water Level =(staff_offset) - (measured water level) - sensor offset. For example, Water Level = 10000 - 5356 - (-103) = 4747 millimeters above staff (benchmark) datum. This sensor is referenced to NAVD 88. See GOES header string for staff (benchmark) offset and sensor offset. See USF COMPS ftp site for sensor heights. Aquatrak sensor height is substituted for staff offset in the above equation to calculate water level relative to NAVD 88.

attrvai.attrvae: Accuracy is +/-0.025 percent of measurement. Calibration (Standard: +/-0.025%, Optional: +/-0.01%); Non-linearity: +/-0.02%; Precision: +/-0.01%; Stability: 0; One year temperature drift: 1 ppm/deg C

attr.attrdef: wind speed sampling period at 1 Hz

attrvai.attrvae: +/-0.3 meters/second; attribute accuracy expressed in attribute units of measure: (meters per second)*10

attr.attrdef: Secondary Wind speed averaged over the 6-minute sampling period with a 10 second sampling period at 1 Hz

attrvai.attrvae: +/-0.3 meters per second; attribute accuracy expressed in attribute units of measure: (meters per second)*10

overview.eaover: The individual environmental observations made at this station are described in the Detailed Description of this metadata record. Each six-minute record of observations is preceded by a row of column headers. Approximately every hour, a GOES transmission header string is inserted into the ASCII data file. This string contains the GOES transmitter message information, transmitter status, and water level benchmark information. This header string is described in the data format file (.fmt) contained in the data file directory for this station on the USF COMPS ftp site. The environmental measurements that were transmitted during that message appear below the header string. The primary and secondary water level values in the data record represent the distance from the sensor to the water surface, so a receding water level will appear as an increase in the value. To obtain the correct water level, use the computation provided in the station's format (.fmt) file with staff (benchmark) offset and sensor offset. Missing values are denoted by -99. Prior to May, 1999, column headers were not inserted in the data file; see the format file ftp://comps.marine.usf.edu/pub/nfb/nfb.fmt) in the USF COMPS ftp server for an explanation of columns in the data files before May, 1999.
overview.eadetcit: See USF COMPS ftp server for format file (ftp://comps.marine.usf.edu/pub/nfb/nfb.fmt),See NOAA GOES transmitter web site for more information about transmitter operation (http://dcs.noaa.gov),See "Users Guide Model 4100 Series Aquatrak" for information about the operation of the water level sensor--available from http://www.cpacc.org/download/4100%20Manual%20070100.pdf,See USF COMPS ftp server for sensor heights referenced to NAVD 88: ftp://comps.marine.usf.edu/pub/comps_stn_details/usfsc_stn_sensor_hts.htm

distinfo.distliab: This server (comps.marine.usf.edu) provides real-time oceanographic data to the public; however, all data are provisional and have not been quality-controlled. While all due care is taken to provide accurate information, provisional data are subject to change or retraction after quality control and before official release. No warranty is made, express or implied, regarding the accuracy or validity of the data, or regarding the suitability of the data for any particular application. This server is not an official source for these data products. For further information please contact the distributor.
